by Bruce Alpert
Ask Alisa Naus about the
quality of pediatric care at
Charing Cross Hospital in London and she will call it a bright
spot in Great Britain's health
care system.
Ask Vivian Roston about
social services provided
throughout the borough of
Camden and she will speak of
dedicated professionals trying
to cope with very limited
funding.
Both Hopkins seniors can
Lecture authoritatively on the
National Health Service, Great
Britain's socialized medical
system. They, along with about
twenty other Hopkins and
Emory University students,
spent six weeks last summer examining London's clinics,
hospital wards, mental health
facilities, and child and day
care services. The course was
part of "an intensive comparative analysis of health care
in Great Britain and the U.S."
The program, for which applications are now available
from Dr. Janet Nankin of the
Center for Metropolitan Planning and Research, combines
lectures, group trips, and individual internships in an effort
to teach students the basics of
Great Britain's "cradle to
grave" health care service. Participants say that this sort of
study is exciting as well as
enlightening.
The four students from
Hopkins and sixteen from
Emory and elsewhere who participated in the program last
year spent the first week, and
one day of each of the succeeding four weeks attending
lectures and seminars on
various health care topics.
. The bulk of the program's
middle four weeks was spent in
internships at various health
care facilities throughout the
London area. Hopkins students
spent three days each week in
such diverse settings as the
MIND mental health group, the
casualty ward at Middlesex
Hospital, and a battered
children program in Camden.
In these surroundings,
students got a feel for the

strengths as well as the limitations of socialized medicine.
Naus found the performance
of Charing Cross Hospital's
pediactric ward impressive. Not
'only did she think the service
good, she also found it prompt
and efficient.
But she added that her experiences were not shared by all
other students, some of whom
were outraged by long lines for
emergency services.
Roston thought the social
services which she saw provided were on par with those of the
United States, but noted that
each month, the directors of
these institutions "have to sort
through huge piles" of applications for services, only a fraction of which will be accepted.
In addition to the lectures,
seminars and internships, participants of the program also
went on field trips once each
week. Some trips, like the one
to St. Christopher's Hospice,
the first of such institutions in
the world, dealt directly with
the program's focus.
Others, like the trip to
Stratford-on-Avon to see the
Royal Shakespeare Company's
production of Julius Caesar ,
gave students an opportunity to
enjoy their new surroundings.
Though enjoyment of the
program seems universal, enthusiasm with the NHS was less
so. In a debate over the NHS
during the program's final
week, a majority of students
wished to take the anti-NHS
side.
Roston thinks the NHS
"looks good on paper," but is
hampered by problems with
funding. Neither she nor Naus
can picture a similar system in
place in the United States,
which Roston says relies much
more on "high technology and
super medicine."
They would be more sympathetic toward a system of national health insurance.
This summer's program will
be the second year Johns
Hopkins has participated in the
course developed at Emory
University in Atlanta. The
University offers five transfer
credits for participants, whose
$1950 tuition costs do not include air fare.

The Council discussed the
fate of Hopkins social life after
Sophomore Class President
Kenny Lee said he felt it was
important for Council to deal
with the issue.
Freshman Class President
Choi Choi noted that the
"social life here hinges on
alcohol." Agreeing with Choi
about the importance of
alcohol in campus social events,
Sophomore Class Representative Jim Farina felt the
University should seek an exemption from the state alcohol
policy. Noting that the policy
was instituted to reduce drunk
driving, Farina said most
students don't drive on campus
and would only be "drunken
walking."
Council Secretary Gregg
Weinstock felt it was unlikely
that Hopkins would be granted
such an exemption, as students
from surrounding colleges such
as Goucher, Loyola and Notre
Dame drive here to attend
Hopkins parties.
Social Director Shawn
Messick felt that in addition to
the alcohol problem, the size of
the school's social budget was
"pathetic." He noted that the
large number of campus groups
splitting up the money for
social events makes big parties
impossible.
Junior Class President Jon
Lana felt that it was largely the
University's responsibility to
provide social life alternatives
and urged the Council to work
together with the administration in finding a solution.
Senior Class Representative
Seth Kaye felt that it was
unlikely that the University
would provide such alternatives, as "the deans couldn't
care less whether we enjoy
ourselves or not."

February Highlights
Ah, February. What a terrible month it is.
Freshmen can no longer sit back and relax.
"I really liked the pass/fail arrangement.
It was like, well, it was similar to going to
camp for a few months. Even the food was
similar, except the food I had one summer
at Camp Winaukee was a little tastier. They
say the food will get better this semester, with
the new facilities and all, but I doubt it.
"Besides the food, there's another problem. Classes count this time around, which
means no more fun and games. We have to
study because now everyone—you know,
graduate schools or our future employers—
will want to know how smart we really are.
"There is a bright spot, though. Rush.
When I first came here, everyone said Rush
was the most social time of the year. But we
can't drink, so what fun is it?"
Sophomores are falling into a mid-year
slump.
"Freshman year was great. I had sex for
the first time. I drank for the first time. And
I had to study for the first time. It was a real
shock, but it was worth it. I just wish I could
do it all over again because now I feel totally lost. I still haven't figured out why I'm
here. Should I be a doctor, lawyer, or a peace
corps volunteer? And why am I taking all
these courses? They're worthless. I'm not
learning anything. All I've learned is to stay
sane long enough to get through the week.
"Then there are my friends who think they
know what they're doing after graduation.
Or do they? Maybe they're all just lying."
Juniors have little time to lie. Those in the
closet must come out because the application process has begun.
"You should have seen it. It was
ridiculous. People waiting on line Wednesday to choose the committee member to
write their recommendation. I wonder if all

of them want to be doctors. It's a tough profession, though the pay is good. That's it.
That's why most of them want to be doctors. They don't want to help people. I
mean, how do you expect them to help people in ten years when they don't even help
anyone but themselves now. Screw
selfishness. Where'd cooperation and compassion go? The same place where student
involvement went; it just vanished one day
and no one's willing to find out where it
went."
Seniors are graduating in May.
"I can't wait to get out of this place.
And especially now during February. Just
look at it. Whenever it rains during the day,.
the mud immediately freezes and you can't
step anywhere without stepping in anyone
else's footprints. And then when everything
melts, it's a real mess, especially the
freshman and upper quads.
"Stairs are another big problem. Look at
Shriver Hall, for instance. The stairs there
still haven't been cleared away.
"No, seriously, I've learned a lot here—
how to study and how to spend my time in
a more productive way. But that's about it.
Ask about facts, and I'll make up some
things to impress you. You know maybe I
should be a writer and forget about all this
application stuff for grad school. It's a real
hassle. Either they're due now or you wait
for the ones you've sent in already. Either
way, the whole thing sucks. And if you don't
get in, there's always employment—that is,
if you could find it. You could work in a lab,
wait on tables, or be a receptionist at a Holiday Inn.
"Then it's time to ask, why did I waste
four years at college?"
It's a good thing that Valentine's Day is
in a couple of weeks.

Clashing Personalities
To the editor:
I picked up a copy of your
newspaper last week, and I was
simply apalled. What's wrong
with the people on your campus? Ever since I read about
your political situation last October, I've been wondering if
the problem is nationwide. It
seems to me that personalities
are the key here. If noone gets
along, then how do you expect
things to get done. A prime example is our own government.
Congress has numerous
members who I'm sure have
different personalities. I'm not
saying that they get things done
but at least they discuss the
issues, and if things work out,
then legislation is passed.
So my question to you is why
can't the personalities be put
aside for now? Settle your differences. You really can't let
this slip away from you because
all of you, one day, will enter
the real world and learn that
people must learn to get along
even if they don't particularly
like each other. It seems to me,
and I have even talked to other
people about it, that you have
a pretty petty, pathetic situation
at Hopkins because, otherwise,
you'll not only put yourselves
to shame but your school, as
well. Stop the abuse already.
Right now, you seem like a
bunch of little kids ganging up
against each other. I just hope

students at other schools aren't
like you. I know your generation is looked upon as
apathetic, self-centered individuals. But there's really no
reason for your behavior. Stop
thinking about yourselvesabout your careers-and start
showing some concern for your
peers.
Mary Brandon

by Edmund Meade
In 1977, the University made
a commitment to establish a
School of Engineering. That
commitment included the
development of a new Department of Civil Engineering. The
new School of Engineering was
organized to renew the University's efforts in education and
research in engineering. These
efforts date back to 1913 when
Hopkins founded its first
engineering school.
The Department of Civil
Engineering, with only four
full-time faculty members,
several faculty with joint appointments, and several parttime professors, is among the
smallest departments in the
School of Engineering and, indeed, even the University as a
whole. This was not always the
case. At one time the department used nearly all the space
available in Latrobe Hall. The
civil engineering program
flourished for many years at
Hopkins and it became the
main source of civil engineers
for the state of Maryland. Interest at Hopkins in civil
engineering, however, gradually fell and the last degree in civil
engineering was granted in
1962. Interest in the other
engineering disciplines also faded with the final result that the
only full-time programs left
were in electrical engineering,
mechanics, and sanitary
engineering. In 1966 the Faculty of Engineering and the
Faculty of Philosophy merged
to create the School of Arts and
Sciences.
After many years of intense
pressure from alumni and
trustees, engineering at
Hopkins again became an

organized entity. This "entity"—the G.W.C. Whiting
School of Engineering—
reopened in September 1979,
and now directs all full and
part-time engineering education
at Hopkins. Before this summer, part-time programs were
under the supervision of the
Evening College. The fact that
part-time programs in all
engineering disciplines never
left Homewood has proved to
be an important factor in the

continuing improvement. The
Johns Hopkins School of
Engineering is also the only institution of higher education in
the Baltimore metropolitan
area that has a complete range
of engineering programs. Even
Morgan State University, which
will be starting an engineering
school, will not have the full
range of programs available at
Hopkins. As Dr. Ross Corotis
said, "with society becoming
more and more technical,

to the region as a whole." The
Whiting School of Engineering

Ask Alisa Naus about the
quality of pediatric care at
Charing Cross Hospital in London and she will call it a bright
spot in Great Britain's health
care system.
Ask Vivian Roston about
social services provided
throughout the borough of
Camden and she will speak of
dedicated professionals trying
to cope with very limited
funding.
Both Hopkins seniors can
Lecture authoritatively on the
National Health Service, Great
Britain's socialized medical
system. They, along with about
twenty other Hopkins and
Emory University students,
spent six weeks last summer examining London's clinics,
hospital wards, mental health
facilities, and child and day
care services. The course was
part of "an intensive comparative analysis of health care
in Great Britain and the U.S."
The program, for which applications are now available
from Dr. Janet Nankin of the
Center for Metropolitan Planning and Research, combines
lectures, group trips, and individual internships in an effort
to teach students the basics of
Great Britain's "cradle to
grave" health care service. Participants say that this sort of
study is exciting as well as
enlightening.
The four students from
Hopkins and sixteen from
Emory and elsewhere who participated in the program last
year spent the first week, and
one day of each of the succeeding four weeks attending
lectures and seminars on
various health care topics.
. The bulk of the program's
middle four weeks was spent in
internships at various health
care facilities throughout the
London area. Hopkins students
spent three days each week in
such diverse settings as the
MIND mental health group, the
casualty ward at Middlesex
Hospital, and a battered
children program in Camden.
In these surroundings,
students got a feel for the

strengths as well as the limitations of socialized medicine.
Naus found the performance
of Charing Cross Hospital's
pediactric ward impressive. Not
'only did she think the service
good, she also found it prompt
and efficient.
But she added that her experiences were not shared by all
other students, some of whom
were outraged by long lines for
emergency services.
Roston thought the social
services which she saw provided were on par with those of the
United States, but noted that
each month, the directors of
these institutions "have to sort
through huge piles" of applications for services, only a fraction of which will be accepted.
In addition to the lectures,
seminars and internships, participants of the program also
went on field trips once each
week. Some trips, like the one
to St. Christopher's Hospice,
the first of such institutions in
the world, dealt directly with
the program's focus.
Others, like the trip to
Stratford-on-Avon to see the
Royal Shakespeare Company's
production of Julius Caesar ,
gave students an opportunity to
enjoy their new surroundings.
Though enjoyment of the
program seems universal, enthusiasm with the NHS was less
so. In a debate over the NHS
during the program's final
week, a majority of students
wished to take the anti-NHS
side.
Roston thinks the NHS
"looks good on paper," but is
hampered by problems with
funding. Neither she nor Naus
can picture a similar system in
place in the United States,
which Roston says relies much
more on "high technology and
super medicine."
They would be more sympathetic toward a system of national health insurance.
This summer's program will
be the second year Johns
Hopkins has participated in the
course developed at Emory
University in Atlanta. The
University offers five transfer
credits for participants, whose
$1950 tuition costs do not include air fare.
